title: Sri Lanka President says willing to support constitutional changes
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s President Gotabaya Rajapaksa has said he is willing to support the Parliament to make constitutional changes, without elaborating on specifics addressing a newly appointed cabinet.
A largely youth led protest in Sri Lanka has asked President to leave office along with his family.
“The legislative power of the country lies with the Parliament,” President Rajapaksa was quoted as saying by his office.
“There is an opportunity to discuss in Parliament the views expressed by various political parties on the required changes in the Constitution and to approve the necessary amendments.
“The President said that he is ready to extend full support to Parliament at any time in this regard.”
President Rajapaksa reversed constitutional changes made by his predecessor that improved the independence of the public service and the judiciary and reduced arbitrary powers of the President.
President Rajapaksa said a decision to ban chemical fertilizer was wrong and the country should have gone to the International Monetary Fund earlier.

Rajapaksa slashed taxes in December 2019 under the advice of his economic team and the central bank prevent the extra money given to the private sector from coming back to the budget via bond auctions by imposing price controls and printing large volumes of money.
Rajapaksa at one time summoned central bank officials and berated them for dragging their feet on extending central bank credit.
